DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to identify the measurable and quantifiable biological parameters test used.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Measurable and quantifiable biological parameters (e.g., specific enzyme concentration, specific hormone concentration, specific gene phenotype distribution in a population, presence of biological substances) which serve as indices for health- and physiology-related assessments, such as disease risk, psychiatric disorders, environmental exposure and its effects, disease diagnosis, metabolic processes, substance abuse, pregnancy, cell line development, epidemiologic studies, etc_Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard._Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Measurable and quantifiable biological parameters (e.g., specific enzyme concentration, specific hormone concentration, specific gene phenotype distribution in a population, presence of biological substances) which serve as indices for health- and physiology-related assessments, such as disease risk, psychiatric disorders, environmental exposure and its effects, disease diagnosis, metabolic processes, substance abuse, pregnancy, cell line development, epidemiologic studies, etc

Concepts.definition: A characteristic that can be objectively measured and serves as an indicator for normal biologic processes, pathogenic processes, state of health or disease, the risk for disease development and/or prognosis, or responsiveness to a particular therapeutic intervention.

Property.preferredDefinition: Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.:Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

Concepts.definition: Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 1/1/11 Released as part of ImageMiner model cleanup.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Measurable and quantifiable biological parameters (e.g., specific enzyme concentration, specific hormone concentration, specific gene phenotype distribution in a population, presence of biological substances) which serve as indices for health- and physiology-related assessments, such as disease risk, psychiatric disorders, environmental exposure and its effects, disease diagnosis, metabolic processes, substance abuse, pregnancy, cell line development, epidemiologic studies, etc_Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acetylation involves the covalent linkage of an acetyl group into an organic molecule.

Concepts.definition: Acetylation involves the covalent linkage of an acetyl group into an organic molecule.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The attachment of a methyl group to a molecule. Usually refers to DNA methylation. The expression level of a gene is often regulated by its methylation state; expressed genes are usually hypomethylated. C0025723: Methylation

Concepts.definition: The covalent chemical or biochemical addition of a methyl group(s) to a compound. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

Concepts.definition: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Protein Cleavage involves hydrolysis by proteolytic enzymes of specific peptide bond(s), forming smaller polypeptides in the target protein during maturation or modification of functional activity.

Concepts.definition: Protein Cleavage involves hydrolysis by proteolytic enzymes of specific peptide bond(s), forming smaller polypeptides in the target protein during maturation or modification of functional activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group forming a type within a larger type.

Concepts.definition: A group forming a type within a larger type.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.: Function; what something is used for.

Concepts.definition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.
The normal action performed by a structure or device.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder.

Concepts.definition: The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.  (NCI): How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.: A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.
How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of a group of complex organic macromolecules that contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and usually sulfur and are composed of one or more chains of amino acids. Proteins are fundamental components of all living cells and include many substances, such as enzymes, hormones, and antibodies, that are necessary for the proper functioning of an organism.: To cause something to start; stimulation of activity.: A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: A group of complex organic macromolecules composed of one or more chains (linear polymers) of alpha-L-amino acids linked by peptide bonds and ranging in size from a few thousand to over 1 million Daltons. Proteins are fundamental genetically encoded components of living cells with specific structures and functions dictated by amino acid sequence.
To cause something to start or to stimulate activity.
A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term that refers to a chemistry test measuring a specific protein or enzyme in the peripheral blood or body fluid.

Concepts.definition: A term that refers to a chemistry test measuring a specific protein or enzyme in the peripheral blood or body fluid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An irregularity in the number of chromosomes, usually in the form of a gain of genetic material. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: An irregularity in the number of chromosomes, usually in the form of a gain of genetic material. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Loss of a portion of a chromosome arm.

Concepts.definition: Loss of a portion of a chromosome arm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: genetic phenomenon due to deletion or mutation in one allele of a polymorphic gene, as detected by expression after cell fusion; used as a test for tumor-promoting mutations; do not confuse with "loss of heterogeneity" which applies to diverse cell populations within a tissue.

Concepts.definition: A genetic variation where gain, loss, or exchange of DNA results in monoallelic loss of function mutations in a diploid cell. In the context of tumor suppressor genes, where a single copy is sufficient for functionality, loss of function for the second allele is associated with tumorigenesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any mutation that appears in the gametes and which will therefore be transmitted to the progeny with some frequency.

Concepts.definition: Any mutation that appears in the gametes and which will therefore be transmitted to the progeny with some frequency.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any mutation with an origin in cells that are not destined to become gametes. As a consequence, such mutations are not transmitted to progeny, though they will be transmitted during any mitosis within the individual. Somatic mutations may contribute to a broad variety of pathologies including cancer.

Concepts.definition: Any mutation with an origin in cells that are not destined to become gametes. As a consequence, such mutations are not transmitted to progeny, though they will be transmitted during any mitosis within the individual. Somatic mutations may contribute to a broad variety of pathologies including cancer.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

Concepts.definition: A characteristic that can be objectively measured and serves as an indicator for normal biologic processes, pathogenic processes, state of health or disease, the risk for disease development and/or prognosis, or responsiveness to a particular therapeutic intervention.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: DCTD (Division of Cancer Treatment and Diagnosis)
